episodes.content:
*First broadcast on February 19, 2019.
Between the 17th and 19th centuries, Christianity was banned in Japan. From the government's viewpoint, the Christian faith had put down roots worryingly quickly after being introduced by Jesuits. During the ban, believers faced unimaginable persecution. But some held onto their faith, and devised ways to worship in secret. In the first half of a two-part special, Japanology Plus introduces the story of the Hidden Christians. Our guests include Kiyomi Morooka, a Catholic priest in Nagasaki Prefecture.
episodes.description: Hidden Christians Part 1: Japan's secret worshippers. Over the course of a two-part special, Peter Barakan visits key locations, and meets diverse experts with valuable insights.
episodes.subtitle: Hidden Christians: Part 1
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on February 26, 2019.
Between the 17th and 19th centuries, Christianity was banned in Japan. During the ban, believers faced unimaginable persecution. But some held onto their faith, and devised ways to worship in secret, often in remote locations such as Nagasaki's Goto Islands. In the second half of a two-part special, Japanology Plus features the Hidden Christians. Our guests include Yoshihiro Sakai, who continues to observe Hidden Christian practices.
episodes.description: Hidden Christians (Part 2): Japan's secret worshippers. In the 2nd half of a two-part special, Peter Barakan visits key locations, and meets diverse experts with valuable insights.
episodes.subtitle: Hidden Christians: Part 2
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on January 7, 2020.
On New Year's Day, Japanese families gather to share a special meal called Osechi. It consists of multiple colorful dishes, often served in multi-tiered boxes. The custom has diversified in recent years, but it remains deeply rooted in Japanese society. This time, our theme is Osechi. Food history researcher Ayao Okumura discusses its little-known origins, and its continued importance. And in Plus One, Matt Alt looks at the chopsticks used to eat Osechi, and what they rest on.
episodes.description: Osechi: New Year's Food. A traditional start to the year. Each time, Peter Barakan meets experts with fascinating cultural insights, while Matt Alt presents an entertaining take on the same theme.
episodes.subtitle: Osechi: New Year's Food
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on November 24, 2020.
The city of Tokyo is normally crowded with tourists at all times of the year, but the COVID-19 pandemic has transformed it. In a series called Tokyo Stories, Peter Barakan meets residents not originally from Japan, to hear how their lives have been affected. This time he speaks with Mateusz Urbanowicz, from Poland. He paints scenes from the city, such as the colorful storefronts of independent shops, and rainy, neon-lit nightscapes. He explains his view of Tokyo's urban development.
episodes.description: Mateusz Urbanowicz: Portraying scenes from the city. In a Tokyo Stories interview, Urbanowicz shows Peter Barakan how he researches his work, and how he sees Tokyo's urban development.
episodes.subtitle: Tokyo Stories #2: Mateusz Urbanowicz
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on November 17, 2020.
The city of Tokyo is normally crowded with tourists, but the COVID-19 pandemic has transformed the city's sightseeing spots. In a series called Tokyo Stories, Peter Barakan meets Tokyo residents who are not originally from Japan, to hear how their lives have been affected. This time he meets Josh Grisdale, who was born in Canada. Due to cerebral palsy, Grisdale has only limited movement in his arms and legs. He talks about his daily life, and the theme of accessibility in the realm of tourism.
episodes.description: Josh Grisdale: Promoting accessible tourism. In a Tokyo Stories interview, Grisdale speaks with Peter Barakan about the theme of accessibility in the realm of tourism.
episodes.subtitle: Tokyo Stories #1: Josh Grisdale
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on December 1, 2020.
The Ainu people are indigenous to Japan, and the Ainu community is now concentrated in Hokkaido Prefecture, the northernmost main island. The Ainu have long maintained a distinct culture and language, but very few speakers of the language remain. In a Japanophiles interview, Peter Barakan meets Anna Bugaeva, a Russian linguist who has spent 2 decades recording and analyzing the Ainu language. She shares some of the insights she has acquired through her long association with Ainu culture.
episodes.description: Anna Bugaeva: A Russian linguist studying the Ainu language. In a Japanophiles interview, Bugaeva tells Peter Barakan about the language of the Ainu, an indigenous people now concentrated in Hokkaido.
episodes.subtitle: Japanophiles: Anna Bugaeva
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on December 22, 2020.
Japan is home to thousands of different mushroom species. Some can be found lining the supermarket shelves, but others serve as natural tourist attractions, and even a poisonous species may be used to make dye. This time on Japanology Plus, our theme is mushrooms. Our main guest is Eguchi Fumio. He talks about his research into the health benefits of mushrooms, and their potential use in new medicines. And in Plus One, we discover some of Japan's more unusual species.
episodes.description: Mushrooms. The incredible diversity of Japan's fungi. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episodes.subtitle: Mushrooms
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on December 29, 2020.
Kamishibai, or paper theater, is a form of storytelling that uses large picture cards. It was wildly popular throughout Japan in the 1930's. Today, it's still enjoyed in kindergartens and libraries. This time, our theme is Kamishibai. Our main guest, Sakai Kyoko, talks about how Kamishibai titles are created, and how they should be performed. And in Plus One, we meet American poet Arthur Binard, whose own Kamishibai communicates the horror of the atomic bomb.
episodes.description: Kamishibai: Paper Theater. Storytelling using picture cards. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episodes.subtitle: Kamishibai: Paper Theater
episodes.title: Japanology Plus

episodes.content:
*First broadcast on January 12, 2021.
This time, our theme is moss. In some countries, it is regarded almost as a weed, but in Japan, it's cherished. Moss can be found in the gardens of temples and shrines, in forests and mountains and even in large cities. Our main guest is Oishi Yoshitaka, an associate professor at Fukui Prefectural University. He introduces us to different species of moss, and explains the role it plays in both the natural world, and in Japanese gardening. And in Plus One, Kanoa makes a beautiful moss terrarium.
episodes.description: Moss. A cherished feature of gardens and natural scenery. Each time, Peter Barakan visits the key locations, and meets experts with fascinating cultural insights.
episodes.subtitle: Moss
episodes.title: Japanology Plus
